overview_of_class: This intensive workshop aims at instructing aspiring screenwriters and playwrights how to write plays, TV scripts and screenplays on various political issues. Those issues are of a wide spectrum; the projects will address sexual/gender orientation and protests against sexual violence or the threat of sexual violence against young people whether in the US or in the refugee camps in the Middle East and elsewhere, protests against racial discrimination, demanding human rights, upheavals against dictators, underground activism against authoritarian regimes.. etc. The course will include a survey about some major dramatists' contributions in political drama, ranging between the Greeks and Brecht. We will review also the principles of dramatic writing. The workshop will tackle censorship issue and how writers manage to avoid it, transcend it, or choose to confront it. There will be some assigned readings, ranging between Shakespeare, Ibsen, Ariel Dorfman and Ali Salem. There will be also some assigned films or clips of features to view and analyze.

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value:
What else would you like students to know about this course?
The course structure will include lectures, viewing films and, possibly, clips of features and short films, reading assignments of some chosen dramatic works, discussions in-class after viewing and reading and in-class workshop on students' projects. Above all, the students will be encouraged to research certain realistic stories about all sorts of injustice and persecution in their own environments and also through international stories based on research.
Writing assignments are arranged to reflect a writer's creative abilities and the process of writing, starting with premises and culminating in completion of approximately the first 30 pages and a synopsis/outline for the remainder of a full length feature film, play or TV script. A complete work of approximately 30 pages may also be developed in consultation with instructor. The class will meet once a week and range between theoretical and practical aspects.

Bio of Instructor: Riad Ismat wrote 7 television serials broadcast by many satellite TV stations in the Middle East and North Africa, besides 12 plays, 6 collections of short stories and several books of criticism. He served as Rector of the Syrian Academy of Dramatic Arts, Director General of State Radio & Television, Ambassador and Minister of Culture, before he chose to leave Syria in 2012 to live in exile.

overview_of_class: To write a science fiction or fantasy film/play/tv show, you must splice together the skills of a screenwriter and a talent for imagining alternate realities - the possible and impossible. Class meetings will include discussions of the classic characteristics of these genres and the varying sub-genres, in-class writing exercises, and group critique. There will be weekly writing assignments and by the end of the quarter, students should have at least four polished scenes, representing the key story moments of their plays and screenplays.

subject: RTVF

overview_of_class:
Description: This intensive writing class will explore the genre of the historical drama - fictional narratives set in an historical context. We will explore the ways in which character and plot can be informed, or even determined, by place and time. Students will refine their ideas for an historical narrative and conduct research that will inspire them to write one. We will study examples of historical dramas (from Shakespeare to Downton Abbey) and ask such questions as: why we are drawn to particular historical narratives at particular times? And what the past can tell us about the present?

Readings, lectures, discussion, screenings, and short writing assignments will lead to the development of a final project: a full-length (90 - 120 pages) screenplay or play.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
In this course, students will learn to use improvisation as a tool to generate ideas,
develop written material, and enrich a writing practice. Through in-class performance exercises, students will explore how to strengthen character, dialogue, and environment in an existing script, as well as how to refine scenes and story structure with attention
to pacing and relationships. Students will learn core tenets of improv performance as developed in Chicago-based theaters, and will have the chance to test experimental techniques based in physical theatre, clown, and Neo-Futurism.
Fostering an atmosphere of collaboration and spontaneity, students will learn how improvisational techniques can be applied professionally in a writer's room setting.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value:
Students will be graded on participation in discussion and performance, short
writing assignments, written response to least two recommended shows, and a final project: the substantial progress (30 to 40 pages) or completion of an original
play, screenplay, or teleplay.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Weekly handouts and readings (TBD) will be distributed in class and available online via CANVAS.
